Class Result<T, TFailure>

The result type is used to eliminate the need for throwing exceptions. The idea is that a function that returns a result will either return a successful value or an error value. The methods of the Result type help you compose and deconstruct this information.

Inheritance
System.Object
Result<T, TFailure>
Result<T>
Namespace: FunctionalLink.Next
Assembly: FunctionalLink.Next.dll
Syntax
public class Result<T, TFailure> : Object
Type Parameters
Name Description
T

The internal value type, if successful
TFailure

The internal failure type, if failed

Used to combine two Results if they are both successful

Declaration
public Result<TResult, TFailure> And<TOther, TResult>(Result<TOther, TFailure> other, Func<T, TOther, TResult> selector)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Result<TOther, TFailure> other

The second result to combine
System.Func<T, TOther, TResult> selector

The function used to combine the values from ResultA and B
Returns
Type Description
Result<TResult, TFailure>

If the Result was successful, the combined value of ResultA and B is returned. Otherwise, the failure from either ResultA or B will be returned

Name Description

Match(Action<T>, Action<TFailure>)

Executes one of the two given actions based on the state of the Result. If the Result was successful, the onSuccess Action will be executed. If not, the onFailure Action will be executed

Declaration
public void Match(Action<T> onSuccess, Action<TFailure> onFailure)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Action<T> onSuccess

The action to execute if the Result was successful
System.Action<TFailure> onFailure

The Action to execute if the Result was not successful

Match<TResult>(Func<T, TResult>, Func<TFailure, TResult>)

Executes one of the two given functions based on the state of the Result and returns a value. If the Result was successful, the onSuccess function will be executed. If not, the onFailure function will be executed

Declaration
public TResult Match<TResult>(Func<T, TResult> onSuccess, Func<TFailure, TResult> onFailure)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Func<T, TResult> onSuccess

The function to execute if the Result was successful
System.Func<TFailure, TResult> onFailure

The function to execute if the Result was not successful
Returns
Type Description
TResult

Returns the result of onSuccess if the Result was successful. Otherwise, the result of onFailure

Type Parameters
Name Description
TResult

Then<TResult>(Func<T, Result<TResult>>)

Executes the given function if the given Result was successful. This overload is the compositional equivalent of Bind, FlatMap, or SelectMany style functions available in other contexts.

This is a special case for mitigating interop between Result<T> and Result<T, TFailure>. Without this handler, the return type is: Result<Result<T>, TFailure>

Declaration
public Result<TResult, string> Then<TResult>(Func<T, Result<TResult>> f)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Func<T, Result<TResult>> f

The function to execute if the Result was successful
Returns
Type Description
Result<TResult, System.String>

Returns another result with either the return value of the given function or the current failure

Name Description
TResult

Operators

Implicit(Failure<TFailure> to Result<T, TFailure>)

An implicit conversion operator for reducing the amount of syntax required for creating failed Results.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Result<T, TFailure>(Failure<TFailure> failure)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Failure<TFailure> failure

The failure message
Returns
Type Description
Result<T, TFailure>

A Result of T
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Result<int,string> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)
        : Failure("Cannot divide by zero"); // this Failure is implicitly converted to Result<int>

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'Failure' Result constructor directly:

public static Result<int,string> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Result<int,string>.Success(a / b)
        : Result<int,string>.Failure("Cannot divide by zero"); // no implicit conversion is done here

Implicit(Success<T> to Result<T, TFailure>)

An implicit conversion operator for reducing the amount of syntax required for creating successful Results.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Result<T, TFailure>(Success<T> success)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Success<T> success

The Success instance to convert
Returns
Type Description
Result<T, TFailure>

A Result of T
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Result<int,string> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)  // this Success is implicitly converted to Result<int,string>
        : Failure("Cannot divide by zero");

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'Failure' Result constructor directly:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Result<int,string>;.Success(a / b)  // no implicit conversion is done here
        : Result<int,string>;.Failure("Cannot divide by zero");
